Combinatorial Structures  and Their Applications, pages 69-87, 1970.  13   LEARNING SUBMODULAR FUNCTIONS USING LOW-RANK DTS  {0, 1}, with probability at least 2/3, outputs a function h : {0, 1}n → [0, 1], such that (cid:107)f − h(cid:107)1 ≤ ∆ + (cid:15), where ∆ = ming∈DT[0,1](r){(cid:107)f − g(cid:107)1}. Further, A runs in time poly(n, 2r, 1/(cid:15)) and uses poly(log n, 2r, 1/(cid:15)) value queries.  Combining Theorems 20 and 1 gives the following agnostic learning algorithm for submodular  functions (the proof is in App. A.4).  Theorem 21 Let Cs denote the class of all submodular functions from {0, 1}n to [0, 1]. There exists an algorithm A that given (cid:15) > 0 and access to value queries of any real-valued f , with probability at least 2/3, outputs a function h, such that (cid:107)f − h(cid:107)1 ≤ ∆ + (cid:15), where ∆ = ming∈Cs{(cid:107)f − g(cid:107)1}. Further, A runs in time poly(n, 21/(cid:15)2) and using poly(log n, 21/(cid:15)2) value queries.  References  D. J. Lehmann B. Lehmann and N. Nisan.
